bestBHT.bht: In this parable, Jesus compares the kingdom of heaven to a merchant seeking goodly pearls. While buying the field may not be necessary for everyone to possess the truth, this parable applies to those who have been trained in the right way. They diligently seek what is true, honest, and just, and eventually come across the one pearl of great price - the efficacious principle of inward and spiritual life. Christ's elect, lost and going astray, are of great love and value to him and are willing to give up everything for him and his grace.

Henry Alford: In this parable our Lord sets before us, that although in ordinary cases of finding ‘the truth as it is in Jesus,’ the buying of the field is the necessary prelude to becoming duly and properly possessed of it; yet there are cases, and those of a nobler kind, where such condition is not necessary.

This case then corresponds to such Christians only as from youth have been trained up in the way which they should go. In these alone can be the settled habits, the effectual self-direction, the convergence to one point of all the powers and tendencies of the soul, which are indicated by the illustration.

But as the same writer goes on to observe, even here there is a discovery, at a particular time. The person has been seeking, and finding, goodly pearls; what is true, honest, just, pure, lovely, and of good report: but at last he finds one pearl of great price–the efficacious principle of inward and spiritual life.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 45. Again, the kingdom of heaven is
like unto a merchantman, seeking goodly pearls.
Philip Schaff: Matthew 13:45. Merchant seeking goodly pearls. One who is making it his business to seek what is valuable, what is true and right.
John Gill: He has sought after them which implies, that they were lost and going astray; expresses his great love to them, value for them, and desire after them.
Christ's finding his elect a chance business; nor have they any intrinsic excellency in them, to denominate them pearls, but by his grace.

Such a soul is willing to part with all for him; with sinful self, and righteous self; and with the honors, riches, and profits of this world; and buy him, his grace and righteousness, without money, and without price.
John Wesley: The kingdom of heaven — That is, one who earnestly seeks for it..."
the Gospel, wherever it is preached, gathers at first both good and bad, who are for a season full of approbation and warm with good desires."
But Christian discipline, and strong, close exhortation, begin that separation in this world, which shall be accomplished by the angels of God in the world to come.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this parable, Jesus describes the kingdom of heaven as a merchant seeking goodly pearls. This refers to those who diligently seek what is valuable, what is true and right. It is not necessary for everyone to go through the process of buying the field in order to possess the truth. This parable is applicable to those who have been trained in the right way from youth, where their souls converge towards the principles of inward and spiritual life. Such individuals have been seeking and finding goodly pearls, but eventually come across the one pearl of great price - the efficacious principle of life. This parable emphasizes the love, value, and desire that Christ has for his elect, who are lost and going astray. It also highlights the willingness of a soul to part with everything for Christ and his grace, without money or price.

Jesus compares the kingdom of heaven to a merchant seeking goodly pearls. This signifies the pursuit of what is valuable, true, and right. While buying the field may not be necessary for everyone to possess the truth, this parable applies to those who have been trained in the right way. They have diligently sought goodly pearls and eventually come across the one pearl of great price, the principle of inward and spiritual life. Christ's elect, lost and going astray, are of great love and value to him and are willing to give up everything for him and his grace.
